You guys should consider changing the data granularity for metrics, daily returns are great when you have a look back of multiple years, but underfits on the 90 day lookback. I think the checkpoints are 6 or 12 hours already?  Should look into testing finer grained data imo.

@entropy, daily returns work well enough for 90-day lookbacks... most statisticians will tell you that a sample size of 30 is good enough.  Having said that, 90-days isn't long enough to take into account a variety of economic conditions and risk conditions, but a finer granularity would not help.  Also, risky investments are typically analyzed with respect to risk-free or benchmark interest rates and the shortest, generally accepted interest rate horizon is the overnight rate (in FX and other traditional financial assets).  Furthermore, given the miners on PTN, if we did introduce a finer time increment, a large number of these periods would have no trades, artificially reducing volatility.  One last point, in multi-year horizons, many performance metrics will use monthly return increments, not daily.
Seems miner incentive distribution curve is now very steep. Top 16 miners receiving nearly all the incentive. Is this related to the validator issue? seems like no

I view the finer/coarser granularity as just having different trade-offs. Lets use the top miner from yesterday as an example.

https://dashboard.taoshi.io/miner/5FWa35Ye9fy1VzWUgS9bvzcTXLDzKaybZ8wL9eER3g1Mu291

When using daily returns you smooth out the large drop and recovery that occurred 12/19.  Metrics will essentially ignore this information because it all occurred within one day.  Giving very good metrics scoring and putting lots of trust in the miner. 

You can see this miner currently is in another large swing. If they recover in a day the metrics will largely ignore the portfolio volatility experienced intra-day. 

Not saying there is a perfect granularity, but given the lookback is 90 days, it might be worth testing other levels of granularity to strike the best balance. And daily returns may prove to stay superior. 
The leaderboard is value metrics heavily over raw returns its important they get accurate picture of the portfolio.

@entropy [ τ, τ ] some of these sharp drops are being picked up in daily returns... short-term calmar ratio is actually hurting this miner.  Just as you said, there is no perfect granularity.  However, daily returns are THE standard shortest-term return increment and it's understood that there can be noise beneath the surface as positions/trades haven't yet been realized.  I been trading stat arb in equities for over 10 years... all trades last 1 day or less... measured on a daily basis, volatility was extremely low... however, getting in and out of trades over ~20 or ~30 minutes was sometimes volatile because positions weren't properly hedged during this process... if performance were being measured on an hourly basis, maybe I would have devised an entirely different method.  However, there is precedence for why daily returns are used.

Hi @ptn・8 , we’re working on improving the accuracy of trade execution by implementing a price slippage model into transactions. When a miner's market order size is large, and the traded asset has low liquidity, it can lead to "walking the order book" which refers to the process where a large market order consumes liquidity across multiple price levels in the order book. This causes the trade to execute at progressively less favorable prices as it moves through successive levels, resulting in significant slippage and lower expected return.

Read more about it in Proposal 16 here: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p16/, and stay posted for a release date in the near future.

As always, we look forward to any feedback!

ANNOUNCEMENT 🚨 

With the advent of EVM on Bittensor and the transition to real position sizing on our subnet, the Proprietary Trading Network (PTN), there will be a requirement for miners to use collateral in the coming weeks.

Adding collateral means that to be a miner on PTN, one must execute their trades with real funds. There are 4 primary purposes for implementing a collateral requirement on PTN:
- Risk Management
- Alignment of Incentives
- Capital Allocation, Margin, & Leverage
- Regulatory Compliance

If you’d like to learn more about our rationale for adding collateral, you can visit our documentation here: https://docs.taoshi.io/reference/collateralrationale/

The amount of collateral a miner needs will be flexible and likely bring down registration costs on PTN, advancing our mission to reduce barriers to entry for traders. 

In the forthcoming weeks, we’ll provide details on how we plan to test the implementation of collateral on the EVM. Stay tuned!

Hey @ptn・8 , proposal 17 (https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p17/) is out for review! 
This is a routine update with tuning the sensitivity of the incentive distribution being the largest change. Here are the changes:

* We are decreasing the softmax temperature from 0.2 to 0.06 which will largely shift emissions to the top 25% of miners.
* Miners will be unable to pass challenge period until 60 full trading days have been observed.
* Miners will be eliminated for exceeding 10% max drawdown.

We look forward to any feedback!

Does SN8 use position drawdown or account drawdown? For example, if you had a position open with one entry using  .1 leverage, the value of the position at it's lowest dropped 10%, what would be considered to be the drawdown? Is it 1%? or 10%?

On the Taoshi Dashboard for a miner, the `Overall Returns vs Drawdown` shows a sort of equity curve where 1.0 is zero returns and under 1.0 is where the account is at a loss. So it looks to be account drawdown right?

Hey @sirouk | TuDudes [τ, ⛏], that's correct that we use account drawdown rather than position drawdown. With a starting total portfolio value of 1.0, 10% drawdown would mean that the portfolio value is now at 0.9. This would be calculated using the unrealized and realized returns across positions.

Eliminating the miners that exceeded 10% mdd is going to make passing the challenge a lot harder and at the same time doubling the impact of narrowing the rewards distribuiton, skewing more towards those ranked in the top 10%
This is definitely fair and the right way to handle it. But things are going to look a lot different for the miners that have been here a while

Actually, I take that back, we are counting all of the in Challenge miners receiving a dusting of rewards in the incentive distirbution. So... that should "take the edge off" of this update in my understanding

@Whit_Delta challenge period currently eliminates miners that exceed a portfolio drawdown of 10%. In the main competition, miners that exceed 10% drawdown are put in a sort of limbo where they are removed from scoring and given a weight of 0 for as long as the drawdown is in their 90-day lookback window. This update involves cleaning this logic up and just eliminating these miners in the main competition. 
Ultimately, it doesn't change much and is a minor improvement.

Hey @ptn・8, we found a bug in the max drawdown logic that resulted in miners not receiving a weight of 0 while having a max drawdown exceeding 10% in the previous 90 days. With this bug, miners are given a weight of 0 if they had a drawdown exceeding 10% in the previous 5 days (captured by the max drawdown penalty), and their calmar ratio is negatively affected by the excessive drawdown. In practice, these miners should have been excluded from scoring and at risk of elimination as per our prior communications on risk management for our miners.

Our goal is to ensure that miners on PTN are using proper risk management, and we are still moving forward with the proposed change of eliminating miners for drawdown exceeding 10%. We will also be updating the calmar ratio with details added here: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p17/. 

To give the community ample time to review the changes, we will postpone integration of proposal 17 until **February 4, 2025**.

Hi @ptn・8, we've been working on testing an order slippage model, and are looking forward to rolling it out this week. As previously mentioned, the slippage model will help bring PTN more in line with real trading outcomes, and further improve the accuracy of the system.

For miners, the order size used to calculate slippage will be equivalent to $100K * (order leverage). Ex: a 0.8x NVDA buy is treated as an 0.8 * $100K = $80K order.

We will also be simultaneously **lowering the leverage limit for equities from 5x to 3x**. This will more closely reflect regular retail equity trading rules as governed by Reg T: https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/regulationt.asp. This will be a forward looking change, and pre-existing positions larger than 3x will be allowed to continue as is. However, new orders may only reduce leverage until it is within the 3x limit.

Hey @Whit_Delta, the issue is with what trading behavior we intend to incentivize and what is currently being incentivized. This is likely due to the weights of each metric not being properly balanced rather than a bug. Although, we don't want to outright exclude event-based traders or traders that trade somewhat infrequently, we definitely want to incentivize active trading. As of right now, the short Calmar metric and its weight isn't as effective at achieving this goal as we would like.

With slippage soon in effect, we’re going to roll out some changes which have been on the back burner in a smaller release. We want to encourage a greater diversity of miners on the platform, as it provides more signal to choose from when building product on PTN. As such, we’ll look to reinstate a more balanced incentive distribution. The consequence of this is that we’ll want to refocus on unique signal contributions in the near future- to avoid any associated complications in the future just run unique, original strategies for each miner.

We will also be looking to repair the lack of significance for recent trades by initially increasing weight on short term calmar ratio, monitoring this to see how much more emphasis we might want to put.

Finally, we’ll be overhauling the martingale penalty. Miners who utilize simple algorithms like TWAP or VWAP to manage positions are currently getting penalized for such capacity management, which will be mandatory as we look to scale in AUM on glitch. As such, we need to give our miners more flexibility. The newly curated risk penalty will look as a breadth of features, including the scaling factor on positions, the number of steps, and timing on orders. Details for all of this will come in a more advanced proposal in the coming days.

Given that these are minor updates, we will look to roll this out within a week barring no major dispute on our implementation. Happy  Valentine’s Day! 💕

In an ideal world from a product perspective, we would have strong signals on every asset and on different time frames. Different strategies have different techniques to generate alpha, ideally we would also have a high diversity of alpha generating composures (uniqueness) for strategies. This allows us to build more tailored strategies on top of PTN for more niche investor preferences.

A concern with a more diffuse incentive distribution is that we may see slight derivatives from a single strategy either by the original miner or by a plagiarist in an attempt to capture multiple top ranking slots. In our opinion, the steeper the incentive distribution, the less of an issue this becomes. A less steep incentive distribution would therefore mean something like plagiarism detection, which has been on our roadmap for rollout for a while, may become a more popular point of development again over the next two-three months 👍

@kabar There's a few things that have been the topic of conversation for us! As many of you know, we're building a tool called Glitch which we will use to convert miner signals into a sellable product. We will tie this directly back into our theta token, you can learn more about it here: https://www.taoshi.io/theta (community call deep dive here https://x.com/taoshiio/status/1887214016784965789?s=46).

A huge amount of effort is going on behind the scenes to bring this vision to life, and we're currently testing our infrastructure for automated trading. Typically solutions to our challenges in glitch are solvable with under the hood infra (hence why we were quiet for a while on the channel). Some things that we feel may be a challenge for anyone building products on our miner signals:

* Size of positions- we see some positions which may be too large for comfortable copy trading. The introduction of more accurate impact modeling (should be very soon) will clean this up
* Speed of positions- anyone building on top of our system needs to have low enough system latency to accurately follow positions. We have some miners who come in and out of positions within minutes, which may be a challenge for some folks building infra to accurately follow.
* Diversity of assets- while we know miners will likely specialize for different asset classes, we want to make sure that every asset listed on PTN has some usable information on output. Some of this will be fixed with upcoming updates to the annualization factors, which should more accurately represent performance for crypto strategies

But to answer your question, the two likely largest changes for miners will come with the update to the risk factor, which will allow miners to start building out for high capacity strategies by using techniques like TWAP. The next is also related to capacity. Currently, all of our miners are assumed to use the same capacity. Having some element for competing using high capacity (large portfolios) will give validators more substance to work with and reach a larger capital base. Larger portfolios will be harder to operate, as transaction sizes will be much larger. A shift to capacity as an element within scoring will be enabled from realistic position sizing, improved impact models on PTN, and the incorporation of a smart contract based collateral system which may be dynamic for the choice of portfolio size

We will of course give plenty of heads up for any major changes here and a roadmap of integration, as well as an opportunity to test infrastructure prior to implementation 🫡

Hi @ptn・8 , you might have noticed some of the hyper parameters changing on PTN recently, and a bit of madness over the weekend as we registered a number of miners. I want to give you a high level summary of what happened, and how we are planning to respond. Prior to the launch of dynamic tao, we artificially set the minimum registration cost with an extremely aggressive decay parameter and a minimum threshold. In practice, this meant that the cost of registering a new miner on PTN was essentially always 2.5 TAO. With the switch to dynamic tao, we were stripped of the ability to set a minimum floor on registration cost, which when coupled with our high decay rate caused the price of registration to collapse. This is problematic for our subnet, where the price of registration needs to have high correspondence with the expected value of returns for miners to mitigate statistical attacks.

As a temporary protection, we prioritized the deregistration of any newly registered miners by setting their immunity period to 0 and their incentive to 0. To resolve the price, we artificially increased the registration cost by registering 40 miners, then tuned the adjustment alpha to substantially reduce the rate of change on the cost. We registered these miners with the following coldkey: `5FjvZbR5Y3QYgpvtMcDSgs3gJQgjB1hT4CuYBPdF3HcRqiG1`. With our prior change to the immunity period and incentive for these miners, all of our newly registered miners should be prioritized in deregistration.

We now have a situation where we had a large number of miners who registered during this artificially low cost period. To resolve this, we are going to permanently disable emissions to all miners who registered between blocks 4916273 (February 13) and 4951874 (February 18). We will refund all miners their registration cost from within this period, and we are now launching an update to restore registrations for new miners. Moving forward, we will prioritize the release of a smart contract based solution for registration, which we plan to release in the coming weeks.
(img showing the change in reg fees and our plan to bring it back up)

@ptn・8 We will be making several improvements to the system in the near future. As outlined previously, we will increase the temperature of our softmax to provide a more even distribution of incentive to our miners. Currently, our recency weighting is split into two categories: a 90-day lookback and a recent calmar ratio examining the prior week of returns. However, the recent penalty doesn't provide enough weighting to the overall score, resulting in a situation where some top miners may not be contributing enough with new signals while maintaining high scores.

To address this, we will eliminate the short-term calmar ratio in favor of a new scoring mechanic that augments the daily returns using a weighted average daily return system. This approach is standard in the prop trading space, with academic works on decayed returns available in the proposal's documentation. In practice, all miner daily returns will adjust the same, so the only impact should be a stronger emphasis on more recent returns. We propose a 40% minimum influence on the daily returns for the oldest entries, which should maintain stability from older returns. We provide visualizations in the proposal to help interpret the functionality. Given that these issues were initially identified by community members, we plan to incorporate these changes in the coming days provided there is no major issue with its implementation.

In the coming days, we will be releasing simulations indicating how we arrived to the specific thresholds for flagging risky behavior. Hi @kabar , thanks for finding this bug, indeed there was an edge case where the times weren't grouped correctly. We will be pushing a patch for this so days will always be tracked between midnight UTC and midnight UTC the following day.

As for short term performance, we now look at a weighted average on daily returns in order to build scoring metrics. This means that in practice, more recent daily returns will have a greater "vote" on the overall average used for miner scoring, although the order of magnitude for each metric should be similar. This allows us to control for the influence of recent activity without additional complexity of new metrics. Please reference the following to see how this new system implemented: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/blob/9965bed9c43495c856301e934afd979bf969f5c3/vali_objects/utils/metrics.py#L44

GM @ptn・8 , we’ve been working behind the scenes on an update to the risk profiling mechanism, and we’re ready to release it this week. As a reminder, this update is part of the first path required to increase capacity on our network, giving miners the opportunity to use TWAP orders without steep penalties from our existing martingale detection system. In general, it is a softening of the risk penalty which is more specific to the type of behavior we are looking to mitigate. We're hoping to integrate it into PTN within the week assuming no objections.

**Summary of changes:**
* Removal of the martingale penalty in favor of our updated risk profiling mechanism
* Breakout of the penalty into a number of scoring categories within risk, which will help to bring more advanced analytics to our miners down the road
* Repair of the daily returns calculation which was miscalculating the start date of each day as noon instead of midnight

To avoid the steepest impact of this risk profiling penalty, use the following rules as a reference. If all three conditions below are met, the position will be flagged as suspicious:
* Stepping three or more times into a position or increasing the max leverage twice on a losing position
* Position uses more than 50% of the available leverage on the trade pair or increases by 150% relative to the entry leverage of the position
* Interval between position times isn’t even, which would flag it safely as a TWAP order

Proposal: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p19/
PR: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/pull/503

Hey had another questions, why is 252 being used to annualize returns and volatility when the ledger is recording calendar days ie. 365*? Since the daily mean for returns and volatility contains weekends when you multiply by 252 and not 365 aren't you reducing returns?
If I understand correctly the ledger is tracking 90/90 days (via 12 hour checkpoints) for each miner, even if they don't trade (0 return).

A crypto strategy that made 1% everyday for 90 days should annualize to 365. A equities strategy that only trades 5 days a week with 1% daily gains will annualize a little over 252 (can't perfectly account for holidays). Right now using 252 reduces that along with volatility. Its conventional in tradfi, but not sure if optimal here unless i'm missing something.

No this is a great point. Normalizing between asset classes for metrics is a bit tricky given their variable daycount. The most straightforward solution here is to have miners stick to a single asset class, and then in fx and equities for example just filter weekends from the daily returns, multiplying the result by a single 252 daycount. Along with convenience in computation, this also provides a more stable guarantee of the cross margin drawdown between asset classes when copy trading a miner, as brokers manage cross margin differently depending on the asset class. We'll likely introduce a measure like this along with collateral, which should simplify the calculations and make life easier for people looking to copy trade our miners.

We'll be releasing an updated roadmap in the near future outlining our current major projects, thoughts on topics like collateral / asset selection, and how we plan to use smart contracts to expand the functionality of PTN

When daily log returns and metrics are calculated the ledger / portfolio still accounts for miners who are flat right? So the daily_log_return is 0 and each miner has 90 days of returns (0s included) right?
You shouldn't need to normalize between the asset if the ledger is on a 365 basis via 90 days periods.
basically the 0 return days account on the weekend account for the extra days when you multiply by 365

There are roughly 62 trading days out of each 90 day period for traditional asset classes.  When you get the mean, for simplicity you can imagine 1% daily returns for each 62 days. 62 out 90 days or 0.68 daily return. When you go to annualize that number 0.68 * 365 = 252, which tracks.

basically DAYS_IN_YEAR = 252  # 252 trading days in a year
should be DAYS_IN_YEAR = 365
 because the ledger tracks every day in the 90 day period regardless if the market is open or not.

If you think of just a single stock, get all the daily returns, but also get all the non-trading days and count those days as a sample, but 0 value. When you calculate the daily mean return you want to annualize by 365 not 252 because you added those 0 days. This will give you the correct annual return.
Currently the ledger counts those 0 days, but then annualizes by 252, reducing returns. (Unless I'm misunderstanding how each day is accounted for).

@entropy [ τ, τ ] Got it - you're right! We'll switch to 365 annualization with the upcoming release, the metrics should be more accurate to reality. There will still be some inconsistency when measuring the volatility due to weekends, but this is already an issue with our current format for incorporating weekends. We'll likely revisit in the future to properly filter for actual trading days by asset class and clean it up further but your recommendation is solid thanks for mentioning
Awesome, glad I could help, it likely will have little / no impact on relative scoring, but hopefully paints a clearer picture of annualized strategy returns.

@dong2810 For what's shown on the dashboard, we take the mean of the average daily return and then multiply it by an annualization factor (365). Please note that the direct returns aren't used as one of the scoring categories, and scoring metrics will use excess return instead (return minus risk free rate): https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/blob/49450b703f08675b72c03ab3f06156f46c8bb411/vali_objects/utils/metrics.py#L80

Previously, miners had to include the `--start-dashboard` flag to run their own local dashboard server, and deal with opening ports or ssh forwarding to view their dashboard from another machine. messages.content:
**[MINERS - UPDATE REQUIRED] **

@ptn・8 Dear miners,

We noticed some hotkeys are not sending orders to all validators. This is an issue because it hinders:
1.  Network decentralization and consensus on Subnet 8
2. Metrics tracking accuracy
3. Realtime data pipelines being built for Glitch

**Required Action:**
- Pull the latest code from the PTN repo immediately and restart your miner
- A version number is now automatically added to miner trade signals as of today
- This change is mandatory. DEADLINE: Saturday, May 17, 2025 12:00:00 PM 
- After the deadline, orders without the current version will be rejected by validators

We hope this version enforcement resolves the issue, which we believe is caused by miners running outdated code.

**If Problem Persists:**
If version enforcement doesn’t resolve the issue, we’ll assume some miners are running code that:
- Intentionally fails to update the metagraph, or
- Unintentionally fails to update the metagraph to due rate limiting or improper local subtensor setup
- Hardcodes specific validators to receive orders

In that case, the Taoshi team will modify validator sync logic so that problematic miners have their incentive further reduced.

**FAQ:**
Q: Why not provide an auto-updater script for miners like validators have?
A: Miners are sensitive to shutdowns due to the real-time nature of trading. If an update interrupts a live process, it could cause missed orders. We’ve left update control to miners to avoid this risk.

**Next Steps:**
- Miners, update your repository now
- Make sure your miner is not using a hardcoded metagraph
- Make sure your miner can refresh the metagraph and send orders properly. Example logs for what to look for here: https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1162384774170677318/1368137680587718756
- Reach out to the team if you hit any issues

Thank you for acting quickly and please let us know if you have any questions.

@Arrash [τ, τ] as a continuation of what I mentioned in the ⁠Novelτy Search⁠ chat, I think it would be worth reconsidering what could be done in place of a burn.

For starters, a burn could be put to better use. For instance, if the IM design of SN8 were to depend on a thermostatic smart contract deployed that would inform weight setting for validators as well as the secondary distribution of Theta (SN8 alpha token) during later phases of this subnet. Perhaps when collateral thresholds are met and miners with greater skin in the game bring more valuable signals, effectively saving rewards for greater intelligence to the network.

IIRC it was @Fish | lium.io who pioneered the storage of what would have been incentive distributed to miners for later purposes that would better serve the subnet and as the owner of the subnet, that's fine. 

The tokenomics of an emissions game that trades intelligence for incentive cannot be a one size fits all. The leadership in Bittensor had the vision to do this when multiple subnets were birthed. Then once again they did it with dTAO, bringing bittensor into more of a feature complete state. 

Now with this we are witnessing the unfolding of dTAO and SN8 is about to demonstrate the greater utility of a derivative of Bittensor's TAO. 

What Fish did with SN51 is a demonstration of a subnet owner's inherent creative liberty to make future plans with the subnet's emissions, by redirecting incentive. The risk this brings is the subnet's security, but this is only temporary. The use of a smart contract could be used to structure such plans while reintroducing a cryptographic guarantee, while maintaining trust in the IM design and purpose for miners to bring intelligence and/or resources in exchange for a more robust game, in exchange for incentive.

Thoughts? What about having the Taoshi team design or contract a designer of smart contract(s) on the Bittensor EVM layer to secure redirected emissions early in your plans, and have it built as a game where miners bring collateral and tiered rewards are unlocked as thresholds are met?

Speaking as an active Bittensor miner who has sunk a lot of time, compute, and real cash into standing up quality predictive models, the abrupt 90 % emission burn feels like we’re being asked to sprint with one leg tied. I get the long-term vision—emissions taper as collateral and true capacity rise—but right now many of us are still amortizing the cost of registration fees, compute optimizations, and the researchers we hired to refine our models. 

With registration fee so high that many of us have recently paid expecting 10x higher returns, it seems unreasonable to make this change without a warning of at least one challenge period of 60 days. Everybody who registered recently and are currently paying developers and quants did so without this knowledge in advance.

Hey everyone, our town hall starts in 5 minutes in Taoshi's Community Discord. You can join the conversation here: https://discord.gg/Jbg6FgeS?event=1371489347383332935

Just wanted to drop a quick thank you to everyone who joined the town hall today. We truly do value your feedback, it's super helpful and we know everyone is busy, so we appreciate your time. We'll provide an update ASAP on the direction we choose to go, and until that point, no changes will be made.

Here are some thoughts of mine post call/town-hall.

The primary goal of the emissions shift is either to reduce wasteful emission spending thereby maintaining token value, or to prevent exploiting the emission system via long-left-curve attacks. 

I will start by explaining why I see that reducing emissions to miners by 90% is an inefficient, and largely harmful way to solve the exploitation issue.

This is a decent paper on the types of strategies I am referring to, very generally. https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4678427

The measures taken by the PTN to solve martingale attacks have largely solved the less sophisticated of these attacks. It has not been a panacea.

During the town-hall I illustrated the fact that every top 5 miner is exploiting the daily granularity of checkpoint frequency to inflate metrics. The method is quite simple, at the start of a checkpoint get into a high volatility position, wait for a measured increase, exit the position. This leads to return curves on paper like the one attached. These would look very very different in any higher resolution.

~70% of miner emissions are currently effectively being given out to the operator(s) of this strategy. This is a clear and extreme inefficiency. 





I point out this extreme inefficiency in the subnet design to illustrate that reducing miner emissions by 90% is not the only, and likely is not the most efficient way to solve the issue of these attacks.  A simple hyperparameter change completely solves the above issue for example.

Additionally, for the purpose of preventing other attacks of this sort increasing reg fees 2X + a 50% emission cut has the exact same effect. Increasing the challenge period also has a protective effect, there are many paths to solve this issue that involve 0 emission cuts to miners.

Additionally, there is an argument to be that reducing miner emissions (once again, by 90%) is not neccesarily the best path to preserving token value.

embeds.title: The Art of Financial Illusion: How to Use Martingale Betting System...

messages.content:
Hey @Barbarian thanks for this feedback, and likewise thanks for sharing during the community call. Some context for the conversation here: in the paper you've cited there are some key indicators of martingales. The first is the unmitigated use of capital and the second is consistent increase of risk after loss.

Our risk profiling penalty hurts miners if they increase leverage on losing positions or double leverage with a loss, the type of behavior cited in the work listed. As such, the miner cited has almost always takes just two orders on a position: open and close (+99% of positions). Likewise, their overall leverage usage is consistent, meaning that they are likely operating on a base signal and entering using the signal as if flipping a coin (no change in leverage over time between positions). As such, there's no immediate evidence that the miner is employing a martingale, which makes the commentary in the paper less helpful.

Likewise, volatility should not be conflated with risk or mistaken for a martingale process—it plays a vital and constructive role in healthy financial markets. However, risk to the network does increase when the relative cost of running miners (and therefore unique) strategies is proportionally cheap (proportional to emissions), as the potency on each individual miner's predictive capacity decreases. As you mentioned, there are a few paths forward:

1. Burn + increased reg to find cost parity between registration and earnings relative to the statistical challenge of running a miner
2. Increase the duration of challenge period to make it proportionally more expensive without a good signal (cost here is the degradation of alpha prior to passing and longer time horizon to benefit)
3. Longer lookback window on scoring (similar effect as above)

As we mentioned on the call, all of this is temporary as collateral will be our long term solution and we will be phasing it into operation in the coming months.

I also encourage anyone interested in the topic to pull the raw positions from our miners at https://request.taoshi.io/ and feel free to contribute in conversation, very open and grateful for feedback

Hi @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ] ...actually option 2. is somewhat close to suggestion I was to make anyway, even without relation to issues you describe...currently miners have 90 days to pass challenge period, but actually the metrics require 60 days to give reasonable values to work on...so it's just 60 days operating blindfolded, and 30 days for algorithm tuning, while those "blindfolded period" still affects total results. My suggestion would be to extend challenge period to 5 months, so that miners have 90 days after initial "blindfolded" 60 days, to optimize algorithm (if they are good enough earlier but after 60 days, they pass challenge period earlier of course). 
This would allow real work on algorithm, not just a guess ... (currently if I want to test new ideas I need to register 10-20 miners, and apply slightly different parameters to each of them, and wait 60 days, to find results, and hope any of them pass immediately, as there is practically no time for optimization for last 30 days if anything was not optimal within first 60 days - as new miner, competing with others with long history and optimization, still need to get to top 15% to pass).
With my proposed approach, less miners would be needed for the start, as there will be possibility to correct errors between days 61 and 150. - And with that, there is no reason why miner registration cost shouldn't be like 15 TAO (or 50 TAO if you wish) instead of 2.5 (only obstacle now is that afair it's hard now to configure floor cost of it) - or if it's not possible because of lack of configurational capabilities, instead, given number of alpha tokens must be hold on the miners key so that can receive emissions or pass challenge (but purely as a replacement of required floor registration cost , not because of a'la ponzi schemes - if there's floor reg fee back-introduced to bittensor, which you as sn owner should insist on, obligatory alpha token holding would be removed)

...and just to clarify - the idea of (temporary, workaround) replacement of high floor reg fee with alpha, is that an algorithm that measures miner performance on every checkpoint , checks out also number of alpha hold on each checkpoint (of even more frequently) by the coldkey associated. and if it's belows threshold, miner performance is zeroed.

@kabar interesting...! Will discuss these ideas with the team. We absolutely want to give miners opportunities to demonstrate a longevity of performance, and our network model should still benefit from non-perfect strategies provided they are orthogonal to existing signals and truly based on strong indicators. A potential risk of increasing challenge period duration too much is that we may run into pressure on the 256 limit for miner slots, causing instability for miners in challenge period. Will discuss, thank you for the feedback!

Hi @ptn・8 , we've heard your feedback, and propose a series of updates to the weight distribution of position returns and to the challenge period/main comp miners that will allow for **no burn**. At a glance, these changes include:

- Increasing the emphasis on recent returns, forcing miners to continue to demonstrate a high level of performance in the main competition.
- Increasing the look back window for evaluation from 90 to 120 days, as well as gradually increasing the length of challenge period from 60 to 120 days. Max length of challenge period is increased to 150 days.
- Increasing the registration cost from 1.5 Tao to 2.5 Tao, increasing capital and capacity.
- Making it easier to promote from challenge period, decreasing from the 75th percentile to the 0th percentile.
- Decreasing the max number of miners in the main competition to 25 miners, and new rules for demotion and elimination from the main competition. If a miner from challenge period exceeds the performance of the worst main competition miner, they will be promoted and the main competition miner demoted.

Together, these updates will improve the quality and consistency of miners that are in the main competition, and more closely align incentive distribution with sustained performance. It will be implemented in stages, with the changes to challenge period and main competition promotion/demotion being integrated in the coming weeks. As always, we welcome and look forward to your feedback.

Read more about proposal 21 here: https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p21/

Hi @ptn・8,
As outlined in Proposal 21 (https://docs.taoshi.io/tips/p21/), we’re rolling out some updates to Challenge Period.
### Updates already live from P21:
**Extended Lookback window**
- The lookback window for miner performance has been increased from 90 to 120 days
- Our scoring decay function now places greater weight on recent performance:
- Most recent 10 days → 25% of total score
- Most recent 30 days → 50% of total score
- Most recent 70 days → 75% of total score
- Most recent 120 days → 100% of total score (full lookback window)
**Challenge Period Difficulty**
- Starting June 6, 2025, the minimum challenge period length began increasing from 60 to 120 days, at a rate of +7 days every 14 days:
    - June 20: Increased to 67 days
  - July 4:  Will increase to 74 days
- The minimum will reach 120 days on October 10, 2025
- The maximum challenge period length has increased immediately from 90 to 150 days.
### Upcoming changes (Effective 6/30)
**Main Competition Limit**
- Main competition will be capped at the top 25 miners.
**Probation Bucket**
- A new probation bucket has been created!
- Miners who fall below the top 25 will be moved into a Probation Bucket
    - Miners have 30 days from the time of demotion to promoted back into the top 25.
  - Miners that fail to be promoted within the window will be eliminated.
**Softmax distribution temperature increase**
- We will increase the temperature of the softmax function from 0.125 to 0.25.
- Increasing the temperature will flatten the distribution, making the weight distribution less extreme and returns have more proportional effect on emissions.

All changes will be on the testnet validator this week. Check it out and please reach out with with any questions or feedback!
